Fortified foods: Many foods, such as cereals, juices, and dairy products, are fortified with vitamins and minerals. Consuming these fortified foods would be a good way to get essential nutrients if fruits and vegetables were no longer available.

Nutrient-rich plant alternatives: Some plants, such as almonds, chia seeds, and quinoa, are nutrient-rich and can be used as alternatives to fruits and vegetables. These plant-based foods are a good source of vitamins, minerals, and other essential nutrients.

Food preservation techniques: Preserving food through canning, freezing, or dehydrating can help to extend the shelf life of fruits and vegetables and make them available for consumption even after they have spoiled.

Urban gardening: Urban gardening involves growing fruits and vegetables in an urban environment, such as a rooftop or a community garden. This can be a good way to get essential vitamins and minerals if fruits and vegetables are no longer available in stores.

Food combinations: Eating a variety of foods that are rich in different vitamins and minerals can help to ensure that the body gets all the essential nutrients it needs. For example, eating a bowl of oatmeal with berries and nuts can provide a good source of vitamins, minerals, and healthy fats.
